subject: Cybersecurity
title: BGP Hijacking: Rerouting the Internet Itself
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on BGP Hijacking: Rerouting the Internet Itself.

hook.text: In 2018, traffic to Amazon's Route 53 DNS was rerouted through Russia. Someone hijacked the internet's routing system.

buildup.text: BGP is the protocol that routes traffic between internet providers. It works on trust â€“ any provider can announce.

discovery.text: A BGP hijack advertises a false route. Traffic destined for one network gets diverted through the attacker's network.

twist.text: Pakistan accidentally knocked YouTube offline worldwide in 2008 while trying to block it domestically â€” a BGP routing mistake.

climax.text: BGP has no built-in verification. The internet's core routing protocol runs on trust between providers â€“ and trust.

punchline.text: Pakistan tried to block YouTube locally. They broke it globally.

quiz.question: Why is BGP hijacking possible?
options: BGP works on trust between providers with no built-in route verification
